title.narrative: Equality Now Nairobi/SOAWR Coalition - All for Maputo Protocol Initiative
Equality Now Nairobi/SOAWR Coalition - All for Maputo Protocol Initiative

description.narrative:
Long term goal The rights of women and girls under the Maputo Protocol are promoted and protected and any violations are remedied.
Mid-term outcomes * At least 2-6 countries targeted by the Maputo Protocol have ratified the Maputo protocol. * Greater domestication of the Maputo Protocol by 8-10 countries that have ratified. * Greater accountability by at least 8-10 countries that have ratified the Maputo Protocol
Short term goals (what is expected to be different at the end of the project period) * Stronger, committed and results-oriented SOAWR Coalition implementing the All for Maputo Protocol Initiative. * Greater public awareness and pressure on governments to ratify, domesticate and implement the Maputo Protocol in 6-8 countries. * Governments of 6-8 countries recognize the importance of ratification, domestication and implementation of the Maputo Protocol.

Recognizing the persistent gender inequality and discriminatory practices against women in Africa, the AU Assembly adopted the Protocol to the African Charter on Human and Peoples Rights on the Rights of Women in Africa 2003 in Maputo, Mozambique. The Maputo Protocol remains one of the most comprehensive and progressive instruments on women’s and girls’ rights with most of its provisions being tailored to the realities of the African continent. However, universal ratification has not been achieved and the domestication and implementation of the Protocol is at best poor.
To amplify the progress, AU launched the All for Maputo Protocol Programme (AMPP) last year (2018) with the objective of universal ratification, domestication and implementation of the Maputo Protocol by all Member States accompanied by enforcement mechanisms involving the African Court on Human and Peoples’ Rights and the AU Special Rapporteur on Women’s Rights. The Solidarity for African Women’s Rights (SOAWR) Coalition, working closely with the AU Women Gender and Development Directorate (WGDD), was involved in the development and design of the AMPP and has been recognized as a key strategic partner in the implementation of the programme.
Sida will contribute with funding of 20 MSEK during 2019-2023 for a project that will support the SOAWR Coalition’s contribution to the achievements of the AMPP and goes under the name “All for Maputo Protocol Initiative”. The project/Initiative is expected to result in; • A stronger coalition of women’s rights organizations engaged in joint action to ensure the implementation of the All for Maputo Protocol Initiative. • An approved and adopted 5-year Strategic Plan to guide the SOAWR Coalition. • A stronger push by CSO actors for the ratification of the Maputo Protocol by the remaining 14 countries to achieve universal ratification. • Improved domestication of the Protocol through national laws, policies and jurisprudence, and implementation. • An informed citizenry that is able to claim the rights of women and girls and are able to hold their governments to account on their obligations under the Protocol. • Greater engagement of different classes of citizens with the Protocol at the national, regional and continental levels – specially targeting the youth, media, creatives, academia and leaders/influencers. • Increased quality reporting to the African Commission within the set guidelines by Member States and CSOs.
Sida will enter into agreement with Equality Now Nairobi, convening the SOAWR Coalition in its function as Secretariat.

Som ett erkännande av den beständiga ojämlikheten och fortsatta diskrimineringen av kvinnor i Afrika så antog den Afrikanska Unionen (AU) ett protokoll till den afrikanska stadgan om mänskliga rättigheter och folkets rättigheter 2003 i Maputo med fokus på kvinnors rättigheter. Därefter kallat Maputoprotokollet. Maputoprotokollet är fortsatt en av de mer omfattande och progressiva instrumenten för att driva kampen för kvinnor och flickors rättigheter, med ett innehåll som är regionalt förankrat. Trots detta har universell ratificering inte uppnåtts och tillämningen av protokollets innehåll är som bäst begränsad.
För att driva på utvecklingen lanserade AU programmet All for Maputo Protocol Programme (AMPP) förra året (2018) med syftet att nå universell ratificering och fullständig tillämpning av protokollets samtliga artiklar. Koalitionen Solidarity for African Women’s Rights (SOAWR), en samlingsorganisation för kvinnorättsorganisationer som arbetar för genomförandet av Maputoprotokollet, har varit instrumentell i framtagandet och utformningen av AMPP tillsammans med AUs Women Gender and Development Directorate (WGDD), och har erkänts som en strategisk partner i genomförandet av programmet.
Sida kommer att bidra med 20 miljoner svenska kronor i finansiering under perioden 2019-2023 till ett projekt som kommer att möjliggöra SOAWRs bidrag till genomförandet av AMPP. Projektet benämns som “The All for Maputo Protocol Initiative” och förväntas resultera i följande: - En starkare koalition/samarbetsplattform av kvinnorättsorganisationer som är engagerade i gemensamt arbete och genomförandet av projektet All for Maputo Protocol Initiative. - En godkänd och antagen 5-årig strategisk plan som styr koalitionens arbete. - Ett starkare tryck från civilsamhällesaktörer för att de 14 länder som ännu inte har ratificerat Maputoprotokollet gör det. - Att fler länder har anpassat nationella juridiska system i enlighet med Maputoprotokollets innehåll. - En bättre informerad allmänhet som har möjlighet att kräva rättigheter för kvinnor och flickor, samt har möjlighet att hålla sina regeringar ansvariga för att leva upp till Maputoprotokollet. - Ökat deltagande och engagemang för Maputoprotokollet på nationell, regional och kontinental nivå – med särskilt fokus på unga, media, personer med kreativa yrken, akademin och personer i ledande position/influencers. - Ökad kvalitativ rapportering på efterlevnaden av Maputoprotokollet till den Afrikanska kommissionen enligt de riktlinjer som bestämts av medlemsstater och civilsamhället.
Sida kommer att sluta avtal med Equality Now Nairobi som sammankallar SOAWR genom sin roll som koalitionens sekretariat.

sector.narrative: Women’s rights organisations and movements, and government institutions

tag.narrative: 5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative:
Examples of results from the previous reporting period:
- Conducted in-country advocacy mission in Sudan which has resulted in the government approving the ratification of both Maputo Protocol (without reservations) and CEDAW (with reservations). However, at time of writing, still awaiting final approval by the Supreme Court.
- Contributed to the monitoring and documenting of Malawis compliance with the MP by supporting Malawian CSOs to develop and submit a shadow report on the states implementation of the protocol.
- Conducted an Audit of laws in both Tunisia and South Africa to establish compliance and domestication of the MP. This is used as an evidence-based tool which will inform advocacy actions towards implementation and lifting of reservations.
- 359 women and youth trained in Sudan on the benefits of the MP and CEDAW. This contributed to awareness raising as well as strengthening the capacity of participants to advocate for the implementation of the MP.
- Multiple guides, training manuals and advocacy tools developed and disseminated to equip and enhance capacities of womens rights activists to advocate for the ratification, implementation and domestication of the MP. These tools have, for example, been distributed in both Sudan and Tunisia to at least 359 and 76 activists respectively.
- In Rwanda, 30 law enforcement agencies, 25 journalists and 30 healthcare providers trained on the MP and the general public educated through TV and radio talk shows and social media. The focus was on SRHR and SOAWR contributed to removing obstacles to womens experiences with safe abortion and SRHR by raising awareness on the MPs article 14, the national laws that comply with this, Rwandas SRHR framework and the embedded rights and available services.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
